Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The 2015 Taan Fiord landslide tsunami: An interdisciplinary study of cause & effect
Award.AbstractNarration:
As glaciers retreat, the ice pressing up against their valley walls disappears. These rock walls then become unstable and can collapse in catastrophic landslides. In Alaska, where this phenomenon is increasingly common, landslides sometimes fall directly into the ocean and trigger a tsunami. This is what happened in October 2015 in the Taan Fiord: the largest rock avalanche in America in decades plunged 150 million tons of debris into the head of the fiord, producing a wave of water that ran 150m up the opposite bank and scoured the forested flanks of the fiord for at least 12km. The goal of the project is to collect observations of this Taan landslide and tsunami, and to deliver a benchmark dataset to the science and engineering communities so that they can better prepare for future disasters.

The project will combine satellite images, field observations and ship-based mapping to constrain the dynamics of the landslide and tsunami, including the mass and velocity of debris when it struck the water, the magnitude of tsunami wave generation and its pattern of motion, and the submarine flow of debris and its deposition. Data collection will take place in the summer of 2016 and will be delivered to the community by the winter.

Performance_Institution.Name: University of Texas Institute for Geophysics

POR.DRECONTENT:
On October 17th, 2015, the largest landslide in North America in decades struck the head of Taan Fiord, an arm of Icy Bay in southeast Alaska, triggering a tsunami that was detected on tide gauges over 400 km away. The landslide was initially detected using a teleseismic landslide force inversion method, developed at LDEO. Our project focused on understanding the effects of these events through a combination of spaceborne, airborne and ground-based remote sensing, along with ground mapping, and numerical modeling. The major goals of the project were to (1) study the subaerial landslide, including the source volume, and supraglacial debris sedimentology; (2) map the submarine landslide, including determination of the deposited volume, flow patterns and any internal structures; (3) map the tsunami traces, including submarine and subaerial morphology, trimlines, etc; (4) map and sample tsunami deposits; (5) evaluate glacier response to the landslide impact; (6) evaluate fjord circulation and sedimentation response to landslide impacts; and (7) evaluate predictions made using the teleseismic method, including bulk mass, direction of motion, etc.

During the 2016 August expedition to map the submarine deposits, we collected high resolution multibeam sonar data of the 2015 Taan Fiord landslide deposit, and the entirety of Taan Fiord.  The  The fjord was mapped by the USGS vessel ‘Gyre’, which also ran sparker seismic profiles to image the sub-bottom sediments. The landslide deposit was also mapped with the UW Tacoma Unmanned Surface Vessel ‘Jokull’, which was able to get closer to shore, and the calving face of the glacier than the larger Gyre. By combining the bathymetry and the seismic data, we are making progress towards constraining the submarine landslide volume.

The offshore team led by the University of Texas at Austin participants accomplished all of the submarine goals.  Specifically we acquired a nearly complete bathymetry survey of Taan Fiord in order to image the submarine portion of the Oct. 17th landslide.  Additionally we acquired a near complete seismic coverage of the landslide deposit successfully imaging through it to observe the erosional base.

In addition to publishing the work in peer-reviewed literature, several team members have been interviewed by the popular press, including for articles in the Alaska Dispatch News (Sept 11, 2016) and Atlas Obscura (March 17, 2017). Additionally, partner Ground Truth Trekking is producing a short documentary film based on the event, and the resultant scientific study. A trailer for the film has been released on Vimeo (https://vimeo.com/186109797) and the full film is nearing completion.

 As an added benefit, this project produced a high-resolution seafloor map of Taan Fiord that will be publically archived and made available as any prior maps of the fjord were rendered useless by the landslide.

 In terms of training, a beginning PhD student Naoma McCall (UT Austin) and a postdoctoral researcher Maureen Walton (USGS) participated on the cruise gaining valuable experience. This project thus may have aided in increasing the diversity in the STEM fields.
